Comment: 1 e4 the standard opening mowl has used for a while, after a little research(his past-game history) I found that he had not often faced the Center-Counter defense my current favorite reply to e4 at the time.
And so I enter into the Center-Counter defense.
I opted to retake with my Queen even with the loss of time after 3. Nc3, the other option 2... Nf6 seems a little passive to me. From here we will follow the main line through 6... Bh5

Now deviating from the standard I continue with my development.

I would have gone for 8. g4 forcing the bishop back even further, of course taking into account the weakening of the King's protection once castled.

But White opts for a different approach and just as in the Ruy Lopez, White pins my Knight to my King with one small difference...
The LSB and Queen are not in the way so I opt to castle Queen-side and prepare for a pawnstorm once White eventually castles King-side.
White takes the Knight and in doing so, disrupts my pawn structure protecting my King. Although White surrenders the bishop pair in doing so.
The logical reply despite the weakening of my King's defense.
Now White pushes the pawn to g4 forcing my LSB to g6
Forced

Not a bad move, yet Ne5 looks better. From e5 the Knight is in a great outpost to help the assault against the enemy King and it would have taken a several moves before I could have safely forced the Knight back.
A defensive measure hindering Ne5
I feel it is time to open up White's position a bit. Since White has already weakened his King's protection, I will weaken it even more.
I feel it is time to open up White's position a bit. Since White has already weakened his King's protection, I will weaken it even more.
White is readying his pieces for a pawnstorm of his own.
hxg4 weakening White's pawn structure protecting his King.
Forced
Preparing Bd6 aiming my DSB towards White's King.

This is where the game starts to get interesting, who's plan will come to fruition first? With a3 White prepares for b4 attacking the Black Queen while at the same time starting his pawnstorm.

I feel that Bf4 was probably the best move here, it would have hindered Bd6(which leads to an eventual checkmate).

With this I align another piece towards the King-side. After this move with the h8 rook already aiming down the h file hindering the White King's movement  I get the first inklings of a brilliant combination.
